page.title: 12 AYNHO: CANAL & RAILWAYS
page.content: The {OXFORD CANAL} runs parallel to the River Cherwell. It was built in the 18th.century to connect the Thames at Oxford to the Midlands. It is a narrow canal with many lifting bridges. There are 2 locks in Aynho, at Nell Bridge and Aynho Weir Lock another which is wider to allow for its shallow depth. The canal is used by pleasure craft and there is a boatyard at Aynho Wharf where you can hire boats from. There are 2 {RAILWAYS} in Aynho which join at Aynho Junction. The older lower line runs from London(Paddington) to Birmingham via Oxford and Banbury; the newer, higher line runs from London (Marylebone) to Banbury via High Wycombe and Bicester. There were 2 railway stations:Aynho for Deddington on the lower line (the building still exists) and Aynho Park Halt on the other.Both closed in 1965
